awd_titl_txt: Targeted Infusion Project: Academic Enhancement of Biology, Ecology and Environmental Sciences Programs at Tennessee State University
awd_abstract_narration:
The Historically Black Colleges and Universities Undergraduate Program (HBCU-UP) through Targeted Infusion Projects supports the development, implementation, and study of evidence-based innovative models and approaches for improving the preparation and success of HBCU undergraduate students so that they may pursue STEM graduate programs and/or careers. The project at Tennessee State University (TSU) seeks to enhance the curricula of the Departments of Biological Sciences, and Agricultural and Environmental Sciences and promote interaction between the students and faculty of the two departments. The proposed activities will enhance integration of research and education in the biology, ecology and environmental sciences (BEES), and provide research opportunities for students through formal instruction and independent research projects. These activities will stimulate students' research interests, enhance their research skills, prepare them for graduate studies, and build a more diverse workforce in BEES. These activities will also increase the retention rate of undergraduate students in Biological, and Agricultural and Environmental Sciences at TSU. Over the three years of the project, more than 300 students enrolled in Biology, Ecology, and other Environmental Sciences courses will benefit directly from this project.

The goal of this project is to enhance undergraduate education in the biology, ecology and environmental sciences (BEES). The proposed project will: 1) improve the undergraduate curriculum and course contents by developing and incorporating new research-related course materials; 2) develop a team-oriented and research skill-based multi-disciplinary learning course involving biology, ecology, plant and soil, and environmental sciences; and 3) provide hands-on research experience to undergraduate students through participation in faculty research projects at the TSU Agricultural Education and Research Center (TSU-AREC). This project will significantly improve undergraduate students' training in BEES, and prepare them for graduate studies and a competitive workforce.
org_div_long_name: Div. of Equity for Excellence in STEM

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

por.por_cntn:
Disclaimer

This Project Outcomes Report for the General Public is displayed verbatim as submitted by the Principal Investigator (PI) for this award. Any opinions, findings, and conclusions or recommendations expressed in this Report are those of the PI and do not necessarily reflect the views of the National Science Foundation; NSF has not approved or endorsed its content.

The overall goal of this project is to enhance undergraduate education in biology, ecology and environmental sciences. The specific objectives include improving the undergraduate curriculum and course contents by developing and incorporating new research-related course materials; developing research skill-based multi-disciplinary learning courses involving biology, ecology, plant and soil, and environmental sciences; and providing hands-on research experience to undergraduate students through participation in faculty research projects at the TSU Agricultural Education and Research Center (AERC).

Intellectual Merit: With the support of this grant, we have improved undergraduate education and research training in ecology and environmental sciences at TSU. Specifically, 1) we have developed new lab modules and course materials and implemented these modules in the courses we taught. More than 300 students have been trained using the improved courses modules. Student performance has been improved. New courses have been created by faculty participants in this project and a new Master in Environmental Science program has been established at TSU. 2) We provided research skill training to undergraduate and graduate students. More than 20 undergraduate students participated in the field research projects at the TSU AERC sponsored by the NSF and USDA and gained hands-on research experience. Students learned how to use field instruments to collect data such as leaf photosynthesis and soil respiration. They also learned experimental design, data analysis, and presented their findings more than 20 times at scientific meetings. Students have won awards for their presentations. Four students pursued MS study after graduation. 3) This project also helped improve the research resources and facilities in ecology and environmental sciences at TSU. Several faculty members participated in this project secured new grants from federal funding agencies and provided more research opportunities for undergraduate and graduate students.

Broader Impacts:  This project considerably impacted undergraduate education and research in ecology and environmental sciences at Tennessee State University through the implementation of improved lab modules, course materials, and hands-on research skill training. Student participated in the project gained valuable knowledge and research skills and improved their interests in ecology and environmental sciences. Research findings were also disseminated through formal publication and presentation at scientific meetings. Overall, this project strengthened curriculum in ecology and environmental sciences, provided intellectual tools for minority students to participate in research projects, and helped build a more diverse workforce in ecology and environmental sciences.


Last Modified: 12/25/2021
Modified by: Dafeng Hui
